properties.Name: Parker Riot
properties.Agents: crowd, encouraged by Alderman Parker went huzzaing to the Cross shouting 'down with the Rumps, and then went to the White Talbott and broke the windows.'
properties.Results: Thomas Farnall, corkcutter, Thomas Cowduck, shoemaker, and others testified against the rioters.
properties.Label: Cheshire, England
properties.Archival sources: Cheshire Archives and Local Studies ZCL/113

properties.Name: Bastille Day Commemorations on July 14
properties.Agents: celebrations in honour of the French Revolution

properties.Name: North Briton No. 45 riot
properties.Agents: `riot at the burning the North Briton No.45': crowd assembles in support of John Wilkes and his publications
properties.Results: public burning of the North Briton No. 45 interrupted by rioters
properties.Label: England

properties.Name: Anniversary of accession riot
properties.Agents: riot at Harwich [Essex] on the anniversary of the accession of King George I; a mob, including fishermen, carried around a person dressed in [?cuckold's] horns; a poor fisherman dressed in ribbons and beating a drum toured the streets. Mentions the participation of one [George] Fairly [Farely] [Fairlie], a commander of one of the King's ships [the 'Hawk'], Mr Smith junior, son of Mr Justice Smith; and Humphrey Parson. The riot coincided with civic celebrations.
properties.Results: Crew of the 'Hawk' defend Captain George Fairlie [Farley][Fairley] and claim he was aboard his ship, firing the guns and drinking the King's health, [in the face of accusations he was involved in an anti-Hanoverian riot]. Aldermen and Burgesses of Harwich support this. Fairlie was unaware of the riot, and the Mayor had given prejudiced evidence against him.
properties.Label: Harwich, Essex

properties.Name: Spa Fields riots
properties.Agents: riots developing from political mass meetings in opposition to government policy
properties.Label: Islington, England

properties.Name: Burning the Duke of Brunswick in Effigy
properties.Agents: proclamation issued at Kennington Common, and stating that the measures intended to prevent a riot would, if implemented, have ensured one.
properties.Results: Enclosed is a printed paper dated 5 November entitled 'Proclamation. O yes! O yes! O yes!' holding up the duke of Brunswick as a victim of his pride, ignorance, ambition and vanity.
properties.Label: Kennington Common, England

properties.Name: [Jacobite] Riot
properties.Agents: riot on 10 June, allegedly supporting the deposed Stuarts
properties.Results: Hugh Sleigh, one of the accused, professed his loyalty to the house of Hanover.
properties.Label: Leeds, England
properties.Archival sources: West Yorkshire Archive Service, Leeds WYL100/PO/3/C/5

properties.Name: (Jacobite) Riots / Thomas Bean Riot
properties.Agents: disturbances in Cheapside [London], White Chappel [Whitechapel, London], and Smithfields [London]; a plan to attack the Bank of England; and a threat against the houses of the Lord Mayor Sir Wm [William] Humpries, Sir Gilbert Heathcote, and Sir Charles Peers, June 1715; more rioting followed in July 1716: an alleged 'Jacobite mob' attacking Mr Reed's Mugg House in Salisbury Court [London]
properties.Results: indictments for riot on 30 September 1716 of James Beaver, William Eldridge, Hester Stibbs, Elinor Hornsby and Ann Lane; execution of Thomas Bean
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Riot (at the merchants' address to the King)
properties.Agents: Thomas HUGHES and Thomas ROSE for riots at St James at the time the merchants of London presented their address to His Majesty.
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Riot in the House
properties.Agents: Riot in the House (Feb 17) [unclear]

properties.Name: Disturbance at the London Corresponding Society
properties.Agents: London Corresponding Society meeting disturbed: The society suspected that the disturbance had been created by persons being sent from the Government for that purpose.
properties.Results: The rioters were turned out and the debate was adjourned.
properties.Label: Lodon, England

properties.Name: London Riot
properties.Agents: working-class protest in favour of parliamentary reform
properties.Label: London, England

properties.Name: Opening of Parliament Riots

properties.Label: London, England

properties.Agents: In the Affair of the Riot at the Guildhall in Lyme when the new made freemen were prevented from being sworn'

properties.Name: Peterloo Massacre
properties.Agents: riot for parliamentary reform
properties.Label: Manchester, Lancashire, England

properties.Name: Doctors' Riot
properties.Agents: illegal procurement of corpses from the graves of the recently deceased caused a mass expression of discontent from poorer New Yorkers, directed primarily at physicians and medical students
properties.Label: New York City

properties.Name: Irish Riot
properties.Agents: riot at Plaistow of Irishmen armed with bludgeons
properties.Label: Plaistow, England

properties.Name: Rugby School Rebellion
properties.Agents: mutiny of the boys at Rugby School against the headmaster, Dr Henry Ingles
properties.Label: Rugby, England

properties.Name: Broomhall Riots
properties.Agents: protest against intended enclosure of land; riot of 27 July, breaking open of the gaol, attack on Broomhall (seat of magistrate [James Wilkinson]), burning of Wilkinson's hayricks, attack on Eyre's house, also saved by military intervention.
properties.Results: On 28 July neighbouring magistrates had been summoned and 150 Special Constables sworn in. A much bigger mob had then assembled to riot, the Riot Act had been read and the military and the constables called out. At 1 am on 29 July the constables were called to Norwood Hall, residence of [James Wheat], where the house had been saved but fire had destroyed the barn and its contents.
properties.Label: Sheffield, Yorkshire

properties.Name: Shrewsbury Riot
properties.Agents: David BELL, John LLOYD and others accused of treasonable riot which happened on 9 June 1750 at Shrewsbury in consequence of a party of people singing a treasonable song called `Charley O'
properties.Label: Shrewsbury, Shropshire

properties.Name: Southwell Riot
properties.Agents: affray at Southwell on 26 July involving Lieutenant [Charles Morgan] and other soldiers of the 76th Regiment, in which a townsman was wounded. Enclosed are the statements of Richard Harris, W Picker and W Stevenson sworn on 27 July 1798 before Sutton and Becher, magistrates for the Liberty of Southwell. Harris states that Morgan 'was in liquor' and his conversation was about Irish affairs. Morgan had said that no English lord should sit as lord lieutenant for Ireland and that the rebels in Ireland were gentlemen of honour. Harris, in the kitchen of the Saracen's Head , warned him to be careful what he said, at which Morgan told him to mind his own business and one of the soldiers drew his sword. Picker states that Morgan was talking of the Irish business. One of the sergeants then claimed that Picker had said that Morgan was not a gentleman. After an altercation the sergeant struck Picker with his fist then Morgan also struck him. Stevenson states that he was at Mr Mansford's, the Cross Keys , Southwell, when Mr Hinds, an ostler from the Saracen's Head , asked for Buckler, the constable. The constable was not there, but Mansford said that soldiers were fighting. Stevenson ran out and saw Morgan struggling to get out of the house and the soldiers trying to keep him in. Edward Carney, a sergeant, then came out with his sword drawn. He struck Samuel Cooke across the thigh with his sword. Cooke then ran to Mr Mansford's door where James Rogart, Mansford's servant, stood with his back to the wall. The sergeant gave an oath and struck Rogart with his sword with all his might, leaving him bleeding. The sergeant then ran to Mr Little's shop door and the mob ran to get out of his way. He turned and ran after Stevenson who gave him the slip but he struck William Hall with his sword across the shoulder, not wounding him as the sword broke. He then ran after Harris with a sweeping brush when Harris was called upon by the constable to assist him. Cooke then came up to the sergeant and knocked him down. Also enclosed is a note from J Faulkner [surgeon] regarding James Raggart [Rogart] who was wounded in the affray. Raggart's wound is said to be very extensive and the inflammation considerable. Annotated: extract of letter and enclosures sent to Colonel [Robert Brownrigg], [Military Secretary to the Duke of York, Commander-in-Chief].
properties.Results: Sutton and his fellow magistrate, the Reverend [John Thomas Becher], investigated
properties.Label: Southwell, England

properties.Name: St. Patrick's Day Riot
properties.Agents: riot between government troops and volunteers on St. Patrick's day, impending court martial after death of dragoon and surgeon's servant.
properties.Label: Staffordshire, England
properties.Archival sources: Staffordshire and Stoke-on-Trent Archive Service: Staffordshire County Record Office D3388/19/10

properties.Name: King's birthday Riot
properties.Agents: riot at Stirling on the king's birthday, when James Campbell of [?Arkinlass], Capt Charles Campbell and others were insulted and wounded.
properties.Label: Stirling, Scotland

properties.Name: Pine Tree Riot
properties.Agents: resistance to British royal authority undertaken by American colonists in New Hampshire
properties.Label: Weare, New Hampshire

properties.Name: Election Riot
properties.Agents: Covent Garden, poll for the Westminster election: great riot '& that Mr Fox's mob of Chairmen and Coalporters hath drove Lord Hood's sailors out of Covent Garden, & knocked down every person of the opposite party who they could distinguish by the ribbons in their hats.'
properties.Results: The regiment involved became known as 'the bloody regiment'.
properties.Label: Westminster, England

properties.Name: Coronation riot

properties.Label: Westminster, London, England
